bibl.title: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, August 7, 1925

div1.p: Frost reviews Carter's manuscript on the history of yellow fever and expresses his hope that Carter will write a continuation on the subject. He wishes him speedy recovery from his illness.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, August 7, 1925
div1.p:
What I feel
most inclined to write you is
of my distress that you should
have had this grievous setback,
but of that I am sure you al-
ready know what I want to
say, and know it much better than
I could put it in any bungling
attempt to actually say it. I do
want to say, though, that with
all my heart I hope it will
prove to be less of a set-back
than you anticipate, and quite
aside from my wishes I am sure
there is good ground to believe
that it will be so -- and of one
thing I am quite certain, that
of all people you are the
best prepared to make the best of it by virtue
of your philosophy and your daughter.

I have fortunately had the better part of
a full day that I could devote to your
manuscript of the “African” section for the
first reading; and if I had not had the
day free I should probably have taken it
anyway, once I got into the manuscript,
for I found it even more fascinating, if
possible than the American section. Quite
aside from the epidemiological argument
it is a liberal education in a chapter of
history that was quite new to me. as it
must be to most people, and the story,
as you have told it, has all the flavor
of the old original narratives, and one
gets from it a good thrill of the romance
-- pretty grim romance to be sure of the
voyages and high adventures themselves.

Coming to the epidemiological argument,
I like the way in which you first bring
over the contrast with America in respect of
the kind of evidence which it is possible to
adduce for Africa -- that because of the
lack of records and of conditions of settlement.
negative evidence from Africa is of little or
no significance, and that because of other
conditions -- the relative insusceptibility of the
negroes, and the small number of European
introduced into the country at any one time
and place, positive evidence must of necessity
be hard or impossible to get
for the days before accurate clini-
cal records & Reliable differentia-
tion of “fevers”. It is clear enough
after you state it and show
why, but very few would have
seen it without a pointing fing-
er as guide.

And I am sure that nobody
but you would have thought of
turning, as you have done, to the
islands and the fleets as the
most likely sources of evidence,
for while it is absolutely logical
there are not many who have
the nose to follow a trail of
logic so far.

Of the positive evidence which
you present that taken from
the account of Drake's expedition
takes hold of me most forci-
bly, partly because it seems to
me to be the most clear-cut
and complete simple item, and
partly because it is such an
excellent example of what a
good nose may pick up on an
old trail that has already been
run over so much. How many
medical historians must have
read of that voyage, and how many
different interpretations they must
have put upon the epidemic.
The facts, as you present them,
make a very strong argument for
the diagnosis of yellow fever; and
certainly in your discussion you
do not overstate the conclusion.
You state it, I think just right, and
I believe that most unbiased
persons will get from the facts a conviction
which is somewhat nearer to certainty than
you (-very properly) indicate. Only one question
occurs to me about the presentation, namely
can typhus be so confidently excluded on the
grounds that you give, that is, chiefly on the
climate? I ask without pretending to much
of either knowledge or thought on the matter,
and because it is the only one of the “exclu-
sions” which is not immediately and entirely
satisfactory. And even here I don't mean to
question your conclusion, but rather to ask
whether it might not be buttressed by addi-
tional reasons, as perhaps that typhus would
have been recognized as a fever familiar at home,
and possibly some other points which you may
have in mind from the spread & fatality of
the epidemic.

The rest of what may be considered “posi-
tive” evidence of the existence of yellow fever
in Africa prior to 1648 is, perhaps, not very
convincing if each item is considered separately
and independently; but taken all together, as
they properly should be, they make a pretty for-
midable array of facts, all aligned to the
same conclusion. Lined up again with the Amer-
ican history, and with your “biological” argu-
ment, they seem to me thoroughly convincing.

When I first read your American section
I wondered a little why you had not
first disposed of the African side; but now
that I've seen the whole
story, I fully agree that the
sequence which you have
followed is much better.
If one should read the African
section first it would give the
impression of being quite incon-
clusive; but taken as a sequel
to the American history it fits
on beautifully as a capstone
to the evidence from that side.

I do not know what further
you may have planned, and
needless to say I hope that what
ever more you have planned
you will have the leisure and
the inclination to carry out. But
in all honesty I do not see
any real necessity for anything
more. What you have written is,
as it stands, a complete history
of yellow fever up to 1648, or
one might say up to the time
(- I don't recall just the date)
when the infection was obviously
implanted on both continents
and admittedly being passed back
& forth between them. What is
more you have shown how the
history of yellow fever -- or indeed
of any disease must be written,
applying new knowledge of its
characteristics to the interpreta-
tion of old and obscure facts.
I think that is perhaps the
greatest contribution of the “History”.
I do not know of anything like it unless
it be Snow's interpretation of the epidemiol-
ogy of Cholera, which is a mate to your History
in the Skill and logic with which the
facts are interpreted and woven together
into an inevitable theory; but Snow did
not have to dig up the facts- i.e. the
general facts for himself.

I can't help wishing, as anyone must
who reads this history, that you may
add to it a history of yellow fever in
later years, for no one else will do it so
will or so delightfully. But I do not think
it is an obligation which rests upon
you as has the writing of this early section--
something which no one else would have
done or could have done. With the lead
that you have given and the source of
information that are available a pretty
satisfactory history of yellow fever in later
years can be written by one who possesses
the requisite diligence, without necessarily
having the genius which was indispensable
in the part you have done. I hope, then,
that you will be content to rest on this
completed work until such time as you
may feel inclined, without pressure, to
take up another “unit”.

I sincerely hope that this will find you
more comfortable than you
have been and on the road
to further improvement. In this
Susan joins me, as in love
to yourself and Miss Laura, and
all good wishes for you both
and in looking forward to seeing
you when you feel like having
visitors.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Wade H. Frost,
P. S. I will return the M S tomorrow
or briefly from any office. Have no
envelope for it here at home.
P. S. If I may add a little to what
I've said, it seems to me that
when one takes the whole set of
facts which you have presented there
really is no escape from the conclu-
sion that yellow fever was introduced
into America after the Spanish invas-
ion. The facts all fit in so completely
on this hypothesis that it is al-
most inconceivable that any other
would be found to fit so well-
the less probable because the
theory which they now fit into is
one of such intricacy.
It is perhaps not unlikely that
further facts bearing upon the history
of yellow fever in the early years
maybe brought to light from other
Sources not now available; but
this does not seem to me to alter
the finality of your argument & con-
clusions, for certainly new facts
cannot contradict older facts,
and I think the facts already
aligned are enough to make
the conclusion a necessary one.
